attributes.title: Systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Conservative versus liberal oxygen therapy for acutely ill medical patients: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q2.value: To examine the risks and benefits of conservative oxygen therapy as compared with usual care in acutely ill patients.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Two review authors will independently screen titles and/or abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy and those from additional sources to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above. The full text of these potentially eligible studies will be retrieved and independently assessed for eligibility by two review team members. Any disagreement between them over the eligibility of particular studies will be resolved through discussion with a third reviewer.

The data to be extracted will include: authors and published information; study setting; study population and participant characteristics; details of the intervention and control conditions; recruitment and study completion rates; outcomes and times of measurement; indicators of acceptability to users; suggested mechanisms of intervention action; information for assessment of the risk of bias.

Trials were considered eligible if they (1) enrolled adults (age≥18) with acutely ill condition; (2) compared a high-target (liberal) or a low-target (conservative) oxygenation strategy; which was measured by any one of the following: fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂), arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂), arterial oxygen saturation (measured by blood analysis), or peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO₂) (3) provided information on an outcome of interest; (4) were an RCT (including both quasi­randomized and cluster­randomized trials). 
Exclusion Criteria. (1) case reports, case series, and observational studies, (2) pregnant or lactating women, (4) patients with chronic respiratory diseases, (5) patients treated with hyperbaric oxygen therapy or elective surgery.

The primary outcome was all-cause mortality at 30 days. Secondary outcomes included mortality at the longest follow-up, good functional outcome (defended by the modified Rankin Scale [mRS] 0-2), risk of hospital-acquired pneumonia, risk of any hospital-acquired infection, quality of life (defended by the 36-item Short Form Health Survey [SF-36]), and hospital length of stay.

We will synthesize the results using the random-effects models for all outcomes. The risk ratio (RR) along with 95% confidence intervals (CI) will be calculated for dichotomous data, and the mean difference (MD) along with 95% CI were used to describe the continuous data. A 2-tailed P value of < 0.05 will be set for statistical significance. Statistical inconsistency will be quantified by use of the I² statistic, with I² values exceeding 50% representing high heterogeneity.

q22.value:
Trial sequential analysis 
We will perform TSA to explore whether cumulative data were adequately powered to evaluate outcomes. TSA (version 0.9.5.10)17 was used to maintain an overall 20% risk of type I error and 90% power. For all-cause mortality, we initially anticipated an intervention effect of a 10 % relative risk reduction, and in further analyses, we used progressively smaller thresholds (15% and 10%) until the optimum sample size exceeded the actual sample size. 
Subgroup analysis
If appropriate data are available, we will perform subgroup analysis assessing the impact of study population, risk of bias, oxygen delivery method, and dose and duration of oxygen exposure.
Sensitivity analyses
Sensitivity analyses are conducted by (1) excluding trials with high or unknown risk of bias, (2) excluding trials with high risk or unknow of bias of the different domains, (3) excluding quasi­randomized or cluster­randomized trials, (4) excluding the largest trial, (5) (6) using fixed-effect models,

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Colloids versus crystalloids in surgical patients: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q2.value: To analyze the efficacy and safety of colloid versus crystalloid in surgical patients.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Two authors conducted independent data extraction and assessed study quality. A Meta-analysis was conducted to calculate the risk ratio (RR) using random-effects models

Inclusion Criteria: Eligible studies met the following PICOS (Patients, Intervention, Comparison Outcomes, and Study design) criteria: 
(1) Population: adults (≥18 years) undergoing scheduled or elective noncardiac surgery, including perioperative (induction or maintenance) and postoperative use of fluid therapy
(2) Intervention: colloid
(3) Comparison intervention: crystalloid  
(4) Outcome: The primary outcome was all-cause mortality at longest follow-up. Secondary outcomes were short-term mortality (death up to 31 days and hospital mortality), and long-term mortality (60 d to 1 year)
(5) Study design: Randomized controlled trials

We will synthesize the results using the random-effects models for all outcomes. The risk ratio (RR) along with 95% confidence intervals (CI) will be calculated for dichotomous data, and the mean difference (MD) along with 95% CI were used to describe the continuous data. A 2-tailed P value of < 0.05 will be set for statistical significance. Statistical inconsistency will be quantified by use of the I² statistic, with I² values exceeding 50% representing high heterogeneity.

q22.value: We performed subgroup analyses based on two prespecified clinically relevant variables to analysis outcomes: type of colloid and type of surgery. Because of the concern that the pathophysiological effect of hyperglycemia may differ between patients with and without cardiac surgery, we stratified trials by surgical setting into 2 categories: (1) cardiac surgery and not cardiac surgery. For trials involving mixed populations, but not presenting separate data for patients with cardiac surgery, we included the pooled results to cardiac surgery subgroup only if ≥ 75% of patients with cardiac surgery. Similarly, we stratified trials by colloid setting into 3 categories: starch, albumin, gelatin. For trials involving mixed colloids, we included the pooled results to a colloid (e.g. Starch) subgroup only if ≥ 75% of patients using it.

Similarly, we stratified trials by colloid setting into 3 categories: starch, albumin, gelatin. attributes.title: A systematic review of decision aids for gender confirming therapy
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to: (i) search for and determine the quality of any existing PDAs developed for patients experiencing gender dysphoria or considering gender confirming treatment options; and (ii) the outcomes associated with their use.

summary.value: The registration document submitted below was formatted for prospero, but they recently reached out to us and said that there's a significant delay (6 months) to register reviews conducted outside the UK. So, we are registering with Open Science Framework. The protocol contains details on study authors, inclusion criteria, search strategy, data sources, study selection, data extraction, and analysis.

registration_responses.summary: The registration document submitted below was formatted for prospero, but they recently reached out to us and said that there's a significant delay (6 months) to register reviews conducted outside the UK. So, we are registering with Open Science Framework. The protocol contains details on study authors, inclusion criteria, search strategy, data sources, study selection, data extraction, and analysis.

q1.value: Efficacy and safety of Bempedoic Acid for Prevention of Cardiovascular Events: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q4.value: Bempedoic Acid will prevent  cardiovascular events

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Two authors conducted independent data extraction and assessed study quality. A Meta-analysis was conducted to calculate the risk ratio (RR) using random-effects models

Eligible studies met the following PICOS (Patients, Intervention, Comparison Outcomes, and Study design) criteria: (1) Population: statin-intolerant patients with hypercholesterolemia (age≥18); (2) Intervention: bempedoic acid ; (3) Comparison intervention: placebo or no treatment

The primary outcome is a composite of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, hospitalization for unstable angina, and coronary revascularization. The time frame of outcomes of cardiovascular events should be longer than 12 months.
Secondary outcomes were cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, hospitalization for unstable angina, coronary revascularization, and new-onset or worsening diabetes. Secondary safety outcomes were major bleeding events, hemorrhagic stroke, and gastrointestinal bleeding events. These outcomes may be defined in individual trials

All meta-analyses were performed using RevMan (5.3.3; The Cochrane Collaboration). Analyses for all outcomes were done on an intention-to-treat basis. Pooled effect sizes were calculated using random-effects models. Dichotomous variables were analyzed using the Mantel-Haenszel method and were expressed as risk ratios (RR). A P value of < 0.05 was set for statistical significance. Heterogeneity was assessed using with the I2 test, with I2 > 50% being considered substantial. We assessed the small study effects using a visual estimate of the funnel plot and using the regression test of Egger’s test, Begg’s test, and Harbord’test when 10 or more trials were pooled.

attributes.title: COVIDiSTRESS global survey v. 1.1 materials pre-registration

summary.value:
The COVIDiSTRESS global survey is an international collaborative undertaking for data gathering on people’s experiences, behavior and attitudes during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, the survey focuses on psychological stress, compliance with behavioral guidelines to slow the spread of Coronavirus, and trust in governmental institutions and their preventive measures, but multiple further items and scales are included for descriptive statistics, further analysis and comparative mapping between participating countries.

To gather comparable data swiftly from across the globe, the collaboration and survey was constructed as an urgent collaborative process in late March 2020.

In this pre-registration, you will find a version of the survey itself and an extended pre-registration text describing versions and data collection procedure. 

•	An annotated list of items with references to individual scales will be made available separately. 
•	Individual hypotheses and plans for analyses of the survey data to appear in separate pre-registrations/registered reports.

registration_responses.summary:
The COVIDiSTRESS global survey is an international collaborative undertaking for data gathering on people’s experiences, behavior and attitudes during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, the survey focuses on psychological stress, compliance with behavioral guidelines to slow the spread of Coronavirus, and trust in governmental institutions and their preventive measures, but multiple further items and scales are included for descriptive statistics, further analysis and comparative mapping between participating countries.

To gather comparable data swiftly from across the globe, the collaboration and survey was constructed as an urgent collaborative process in late March 2020.

In this pre-registration, you will find a version of the survey itself and an extended pre-registration text describing versions and data collection procedure. 

•	An annotated list of items with references to individual scales will be made available separately. 
•	Individual hypotheses and plans for analyses of the survey data to appear in separate pre-registrations/registered reports.

summary.value: The upcoming experiment will be the fourth, following experiment 3 that aimed to test cognitive demand, i.e., the effect of mere addition of fillers without semantic relevance. The present experiment is a replication of experiment 3 with different fillers. Hence, this experiment 4 will be precisely the same in every respect as preregistered for the preceding experiment 3 (at https://osf.io/b4ghe), with the exception of the presented filler items: instead of neutral fillers and number fillers, there will be pseudoword fillers and arrow-like symbols fillers (pointing right for target, pointing left for nontarget).

registration_responses.summary: The upcoming experiment will be the fourth, following experiment 3 that aimed to test cognitive demand, i.e., the effect of mere addition of fillers without semantic relevance. The present experiment is a replication of experiment 3 with different fillers. Hence, this experiment 4 will be precisely the same in every respect as preregistered for the preceding experiment 3 (at https://osf.io/b4ghe), with the exception of the presented filler items: instead of neutral fillers and number fillers, there will be pseudoword fillers and arrow-like symbols fillers (pointing right for target, pointing left for nontarget).

summary.value:
# Main questions


This experiment follows Experiment 1 that tested proportions and visual distinctness. The present experiment aims to test semantic relevance (and direction), as well as a repeated testing of visual distinctness.

The semantic relevance of fillers will be tested by switching the required response keys for familiar- vs. unfamiliar fillers. That is, one condition will be as usual (familiar fillers categorized together with targets, unfamiliar opposite), but in another condition the familiar fillers will have to be categorized together with the probe and irrelevant items, while unfamiliar fillers have to be categorized together with the target. We assume that switching the response keys will substantially decrease probe-minus-irrelevant differences. This would prove that (a) the familiarity-related meaning of fillers matters, since otherwise the direction could not matter, and (b) that direction matters, too (since, otherwise, one may argue that the mere presence of familiarity-relatedness has an effect).

The visual distinctness was tested in Experiment 1, and here we test it further in a slightly different way: In Experiment 1, the fillers changed between uppercase and lowercase, while here the main items (probe, irrelevant, target) will change between uppercase and lowercase. Furthermore, to further increase visual distinctness, fillers will be either underlined or not underlined, in different blocks. (These factors will all be tested within-subject, without changing filler proportion as in Experiment 1, where the (carry-over) effects may have to some extent interfered with this factor.)

Importantly, we are not interested in the interaction between these two factors, the experiment includes both factors at the same time simply to be economical. Since one factor is within-subject, and the other is between-subjects, they will not interfere with each other.

# Experimental design

Same as in Experiment 1, only Knowledgeable conditions will be run (i.e., the probes are known to all participants, simulating guilt). 

There will be one between-subjects factor of “filler direction”: fillers in “normal direction” (familiar filler together with target) vs. filler in “reverse direction”, that is, with reversed response keys (familiar opposite to target). In both conditions, the ratio will be kept the same (three fillers together with target, six fillers opposite to target). (There will be a fix group of six words for familiar and unfamiliar fillers. When six is needed – categorized opposite of target – all six used are from either category. When only three is needed – categorized together with target – the three will always be randomly chosen from the given group of six words.) 

Furthermore, there will be two within-subject factors, both regarding visual distinctness, each with two levels: Lettercase (lowercase vs. uppercase main items) and Underlining (underlined vs. not underlined fillers). Each participant will be tested in four blocks (always with country of origin as probe): The first two blocks will both have either underlined or not underlined fillers; whereas the last two blocks will both have the reverse proportion. The main item lettercase will alternate per each block: e.g., first lowercase, then uppercase, then again lowercase, then again uppercase – otherwise the reverse (first uppercase, then lowercase, etc.). The orders (for either factor) are assigned randomly.

# Participants

Data will be collected online: First, 120 slots will be opened on the Figure Eight platform. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups.

If the Bayes factor for the test between “normal direction” and “reverse direction” conditions for reaction time (RT) mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 60 additional slots will be opened (allowing participants in both conditions). The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed for each of the two conditions.

Otherwise, if the Bayes factor for either of the two Visual Distinctness main effects (Lettercase or Underlining) in the related analysis of variance (ANOVA) for RT mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 30 additional slots will be opened in the “normal direction” condition only. The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed for this condition.

# Exclusions

Those participants who do not select their true country of origin correctly in a final check at the end of the RT-Concealed Information Test (CIT) will be excluded. (In the actual task, a second attempt for correct selection is allowed for exploratory purposes, but failure for the first time already means exclusion in the present analysis.) Similarly as in our most recent studies: We will exclude all participants with accuracy rate for the main items (probes and irrelevants merged) not higher than 75%, and with accuracy rate not higher than 50% for any of the following item types: (1) target items, (2) self-referring fillers, (3) other-referring fillers.

For all further analysis, responses below 150 ms will be excluded. For RT analysis, only correctly responded to trials will be used (i.e., we exclude all trials with incorrect or too slow responses). For keypress duration analysis only, keypress durations longer than 200 ms will be excluded.

# Main analysis

We use a simple t-test (Welch-corrected) to compare “normal direction” and “reverse direction” conditions (between-subject), for probe-irrelevant RT mean differences (mean probe RT minus mean irrelevant RT; using all valid, correct trials), complemented by Bayes factor (with the default r-scale of 0.707). For this, the four block results will be merged into one value per participant.

For Visual Distinctness, we use a 2 by 2 ANOVA for the probe-irrelevant RT mean differences in “normal direction” condition only, with appropriate follow-up t-tests. We report Bayes factors for the ANOVA (inclusion BF based on matched models) as well as the t-tests (with the default r-scale of 0.707).

# Secondary analysis

We perform all tests using accuracy rates (ratio of correct responses to correct, incorrect, and too slow responses) and keypress duration means in place of mean RTs.

To calculate illustrative areas under curves (AUCs) for probe-irrelevant mean RT differences as predictors, we will simulate control groups, for the real RT data from each of the conditions, using 1,000 near-perfectly distributed values with a mean of zero and an SD derived from the real data (from each condition) as real_SD * 0.5 + 7 (ms).

registration_responses.summary:
# Main questions


This experiment follows Experiment 1 that tested proportions and visual distinctness. The present experiment aims to test semantic relevance (and direction), as well as a repeated testing of visual distinctness.

The semantic relevance of fillers will be tested by switching the required response keys for familiar- vs. unfamiliar fillers. That is, one condition will be as usual (familiar fillers categorized together with targets, unfamiliar opposite), but in another condition the familiar fillers will have to be categorized together with the probe and irrelevant items, while unfamiliar fillers have to be categorized together with the target. We assume that switching the response keys will substantially decrease probe-minus-irrelevant differences. This would prove that (a) the familiarity-related meaning of fillers matters, since otherwise the direction could not matter, and (b) that direction matters, too (since, otherwise, one may argue that the mere presence of familiarity-relatedness has an effect).

The visual distinctness was tested in Experiment 1, and here we test it further in a slightly different way: In Experiment 1, the fillers changed between uppercase and lowercase, while here the main items (probe, irrelevant, target) will change between uppercase and lowercase. Furthermore, to further increase visual distinctness, fillers will be either underlined or not underlined, in different blocks. (These factors will all be tested within-subject, without changing filler proportion as in Experiment 1, where the (carry-over) effects may have to some extent interfered with this factor.)

Importantly, we are not interested in the interaction between these two factors, the experiment includes both factors at the same time simply to be economical. Since one factor is within-subject, and the other is between-subjects, they will not interfere with each other.

# Experimental design

Same as in Experiment 1, only Knowledgeable conditions will be run (i.e., the probes are known to all participants, simulating guilt). 

There will be one between-subjects factor of “filler direction”: fillers in “normal direction” (familiar filler together with target) vs. filler in “reverse direction”, that is, with reversed response keys (familiar opposite to target). In both conditions, the ratio will be kept the same (three fillers together with target, six fillers opposite to target). (There will be a fix group of six words for familiar and unfamiliar fillers. When six is needed – categorized opposite of target – all six used are from either category. When only three is needed – categorized together with target – the three will always be randomly chosen from the given group of six words.) 

Furthermore, there will be two within-subject factors, both regarding visual distinctness, each with two levels: Lettercase (lowercase vs. uppercase main items) and Underlining (underlined vs. not underlined fillers). Each participant will be tested in four blocks (always with country of origin as probe): The first two blocks will both have either underlined or not underlined fillers; whereas the last two blocks will both have the reverse proportion. The main item lettercase will alternate per each block: e.g., first lowercase, then uppercase, then again lowercase, then again uppercase – otherwise the reverse (first uppercase, then lowercase, etc.). The orders (for either factor) are assigned randomly.

# Participants

Data will be collected online: First, 120 slots will be opened on the Figure Eight platform. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups.

If the Bayes factor for the test between “normal direction” and “reverse direction” conditions for reaction time (RT) mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 60 additional slots will be opened (allowing participants in both conditions). The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed for each of the two conditions.

Otherwise, if the Bayes factor for either of the two Visual Distinctness main effects (Lettercase or Underlining) in the related analysis of variance (ANOVA) for RT mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 30 additional slots will be opened in the “normal direction” condition only. The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed for this condition.

# Exclusions

Those participants who do not select their true country of origin correctly in a final check at the end of the RT-Concealed Information Test (CIT) will be excluded. (In the actual task, a second attempt for correct selection is allowed for exploratory purposes, but failure for the first time already means exclusion in the present analysis.) Similarly as in our most recent studies: We will exclude all participants with accuracy rate for the main items (probes and irrelevants merged) not higher than 75%, and with accuracy rate not higher than 50% for any of the following item types: (1) target items, (2) self-referring fillers, (3) other-referring fillers.

For all further analysis, responses below 150 ms will be excluded. For RT analysis, only correctly responded to trials will be used (i.e., we exclude all trials with incorrect or too slow responses). For keypress duration analysis only, keypress durations longer than 200 ms will be excluded.

# Main analysis

We use a simple t-test (Welch-corrected) to compare “normal direction” and “reverse direction” conditions (between-subject), for probe-irrelevant RT mean differences (mean probe RT minus mean irrelevant RT; using all valid, correct trials), complemented by Bayes factor (with the default r-scale of 0.707). For this, the four block results will be merged into one value per participant.

For Visual Distinctness, we use a 2 by 2 ANOVA for the probe-irrelevant RT mean differences in “normal direction” condition only, with appropriate follow-up t-tests. We report Bayes factors for the ANOVA (inclusion BF based on matched models) as well as the t-tests (with the default r-scale of 0.707).

# Secondary analysis

We perform all tests using accuracy rates (ratio of correct responses to correct, incorrect, and too slow responses) and keypress duration means in place of mean RTs.

To calculate illustrative areas under curves (AUCs) for probe-irrelevant mean RT differences as predictors, we will simulate control groups, for the real RT data from each of the conditions, using 1,000 near-perfectly distributed values with a mean of zero and an SD derived from the real data (from each condition) as real_SD * 0.5 + 7 (ms).

summary.value:
# Main questions

This experiment follows Experiments 1 and 2 that tested proportions, visual distinctiveness, and semantic relevance. The present experiment aims to test cognitive demand, i.e., the effect of mere addition of fillers without semantic relevance. For this, semantically neutral fillers will be used and compared against the version with no fillers. Furthermore, neutral fillers will be of two categories: (a) almost completely meaningless fillers (strings of numbers, e.g., „11111”, „22222”, etc.), and (b) meaningful but not related to the recognition (or deception) context of the test (use of animate vs. inanimate concepts).

# Experimental design

Same as in Experiments 1 and 2, only Knowledgeable conditions will be run (i.e., the probes are known to all participants, simulating guilt). 

There will be one within-subject factor “Filler Type”: (a) no fillers at all, (b) meaningless fillers, (c) neutral (but meaningful) fillers. Each is presented in a separate block, in random order.
 
# Participants

Data will be collected online: First, 60 slots will be opened on the Figure Eight platform. If the Bayes factor for any of the three main t-tests (see below) between the conditions for reaction time (RT) mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 30 additional slots will be opened. The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed.

# Exclusions

Those participants who do not select their true country of origin correctly in a final check at the end of the RT-Concealed Information Test (CIT) will be excluded. (In the actual task, a second attempt for correct selection is allowed for exploratory purposes, but failure for the first time already means exclusion in the present analysis.) Similarly as in our most recent studies: We will exclude all participants with accuracy rate for the main items (probes and irrelevants merged) not higher than 75%, and with accuracy rate not higher than 50% for any of the following item types: (1) target items, (2) all left-side fillers, (3) all right-side fillers.

For all further analysis, responses below 150 ms will be excluded. For RT analysis, only correctly responded to trials will be used (i.e., we exclude all trials with incorrect or too slow responses). For keypress duration analysis only, keypress durations longer than 200 ms will be excluded.

# Main analysis

We first perform a one-way (Welch-corrected) ANOVA on the within-subject factor Filler Type, complemented by Bayes factor (with the default r-scale of 0.707). As follow-up, we use three t-tests for comparisons between any two of the three conditions (no filler, meaningless filler, neutral filler), for probe-irrelevant RT mean differences (mean probe RT minus mean irrelevant RT; using all valid, correct trials), complemented by Bayes factors (with the default r-scale of 0.707). For the comparisons between the “no filler” versus “meaningless filler”, and between the “no filler” versus “neutral filler” conditions, we use one-sided t-tests, expecting smaller RT mean differences in the “no filler” condition in both cases. We use a two-sided t-test between the “meaningless filler” and “neutral filler” conditions (although we do suspect that the latter will have larger values, since it presumably poses greater cognitive demand).

# Secondary analysis

We perform all tests using accuracy rates (ratio of correct responses to correct, incorrect, and too slow responses) and keypress duration means in place of mean RTs.

To calculate illustrative areas under curves (AUCs) for probe-irrelevant mean RT differences as predictors, we will simulate control groups, for the real RT data from each of the conditions, using 1,000 near-perfectly distributed values with a mean of zero and an SD derived from the real data (from each condition) as real_SD * 0.5 + 7 (ms).

registration_responses.summary:
# Main questions

This experiment follows Experiments 1 and 2 that tested proportions, visual distinctiveness, and semantic relevance. The present experiment aims to test cognitive demand, i.e., the effect of mere addition of fillers without semantic relevance. For this, semantically neutral fillers will be used and compared against the version with no fillers. Furthermore, neutral fillers will be of two categories: (a) almost completely meaningless fillers (strings of numbers, e.g., „11111”, „22222”, etc.), and (b) meaningful but not related to the recognition (or deception) context of the test (use of animate vs. inanimate concepts).

# Participants

If the Bayes factor for any of the three main t-tests (see below) between the conditions for reaction time (RT) mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 30 additional slots will be opened. The addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid (i.e., not excluded, see below) completed tests are reached or passed.

# Exclusions

(In the actual task, a second attempt for correct selection is allowed for exploratory purposes, but failure for the first time already means exclusion in the present analysis.) Similarly as in our most recent studies: We will exclude all participants with accuracy rate for the main items (probes and irrelevants merged) not higher than 75%, and with accuracy rate not higher than 50% for any of the following item types: (1) target items, (2) all left-side fillers, (3) all right-side fillers.

For all further analysis, responses below 150 ms will be excluded. For RT analysis, only correctly responded to trials will be used (i.e., we exclude all trials with incorrect or too slow responses). For keypress duration analysis only, keypress durations longer than 200 ms will be excluded.

# Main analysis

summary.value:
# Main questions

This experiment tests whether different proportions of familiar- and unfamiliar-referring filler items (i.e., more familiar-referring vs. more unfamiliar-referring) in the RT-CIT influence the outcome (probe-irrelevant differences). The smaller proportion (3:6) of familiar- relative to unfamiliar-referring items in the original task (Lukács, Kleinberg, & Verschuere, 2017) was intended to keep to “target-side” items (i.e., the target and items to be categorized with the same key as the target) less frequent than the rest of the items, hence, keeping the uniqueness of the target (or all target-side items). This uniqueness (or “pop-out”) of target-referring items is assumed to be a factor in eliciting response conflict in case of, in this respect similar, probes among the irrelevant items (Lukács & Ansorge, 2019, ACP), thereby, contributing to larger probe-irrelevant differences. Nonetheless, it is also theoretically possible that these familiarity-related fillers play no role in the subjective “target-nontarget” categorization of examinees, but instead play a separate role in the “familiar-unfamiliar” dimension only. We therefore compare the original, 3:6 familiar:unfamiliar version with a version with a reverse proportion (larger, 6:3, proportion of familiar- to unfamiliar-referring items) to the original version.

Relatedly, we also examine whether visually more distinct fillers (lowercase as opposed to uppercase main [probe, target, irrelevant] items) influence the outcome (see Lukács et al. 2019; APB). Firstly, if the visual distinction separates the two tasks from the participants’ perspective, it could replace other, more semantic distinctions and the proportion should matter less: that is, a Distinctness x Proportion interaction would be found with smaller difference between different proportions (more familiar or less familiar fillers) when the fillers are visually distinct (i.e., presented in lowercase). Secondly, the larger visual distinction between the two item categories may lead to more distinct attention to each of these two separate (though alternating) tasks (target-nontarget main items, and familiar-unfamiliar fillers), and thereby increase probe versus irrelevant effect sizes (as well as, incidentally, familiar versus unfamiliar filler effect sizes).

# Experimental design

In this experiment, only Knowledgeable conditions will be run (i.e., the probes are known to all participants, simulating guilt). There will be two within-subject factors, each with two levels: Proportion (less familiar-referring fillers versus more familiar-referring fillers) and Distinctness (lowercase fillers versus uppercase fillers; while main items are always uppercase as it is conventional). Each participant will be tested in four blocks (always with country of origin as probe): The first two blocks will both have either larger proportion or smaller proportion of familiar-referring fillers; whereas the last two blocks will both have the reverse proportion. The filler lettercase will alternate per each block: e.g., first lowercase, then uppercase, then again lowercase, then again uppercase – otherwise the reverse (first uppercase, then lowercase, etc.). The orders (for either factor) are assigned randomly.

# Participants

Data will be collected online: first, 60 slots will be opened on the Figure Eight platform. 
If the Bayes factor for any of the effects (either of two main effects or the interaction) in the main ANOVA for RT mean probe-irrelevant differences (see below) does not reach a minimum of 5 in either direction (i.e., technically below at least 1/5 when supporting null hypothesis), 30 additional slots will be opened. This addition will be repeated until all likelihood ratios reach at least 5 or until a maximum of 120 valid completed tests are reached or passed.

# Exclusions

Those participants who do not select their true country of origin correctly in a final check at the end of the RT-CIT will be excluded. (In the actual task a second attempt for correct selection is allowed for exploratory purposes, but failure for the first time already means exclusion in the present analysis.) Similarly as in our most recent studies: We will exclude all participants with accuracy rate for the main items (probes and irrelevants merged) not higher than 75%, and with accuracy rate not higher than 50% for any of the following item types: (1) target items, (2) self-referring fillers, (3) other-referring fillers.

For all further analysis, responses below 150 ms will be excluded. For RT analysis, only correctly responded to trials will be used (i.e., we exclude all trials with incorrect or too slow responses). For keypress duration analysis only, keypress durations longer than 200 ms will be excluded.

# Main analysis

The main test will be a 2 by 2 ANOVA for the probe-irrelevant response time (RT) mean differences (mean probe RT minus mean irrelevant RT; using all valid, correct trials), with appropriate follow-up t-tests. We report Bayes factors for the ANOVA (inclusion BF based on matched models) as well as the t-tests (with the default r-scale of 0.707).

# Secondary analysis

Same as for RTs, we also perform the ANOVA for probe-irrelevant differences in accuracy rate (ratio of correct responses to correct, incorrect, and too slow responses), and for keypress durations.

To calculate illustrative areas under curves (AUCs) for probe-irrelevant mean RT differences as predictors, we will simulate control groups, for the real RT data from each of the four possible conditions, using 1,000 near-perfectly distributed values with a mean of zero and an SD derived from the real data (from each condition) as real_SD * 0.5 + 7 (ms).

# Main questions

This experiment tests whether different proportions of familiar- and unfamiliar-referring filler items (i.e., more familiar-referring vs. more unfamiliar-referring) in the RT-CIT influence the outcome (probe-irrelevant differences). The smaller proportion (3:6) of familiar- relative to unfamiliar-referring items in the original task (Lukács, Kleinberg, & Verschuere, 2017) was intended to keep to “target-side” items (i.e., the target and items to be categorized with the same key as the target) less frequent than the rest of the items, hence, keeping the uniqueness of the target (or all target-side items). attributes.title: Investigating the impact of thought probe format on the measurement of mind wandering
attributes.description: Over the past decade, research on the topic of mind wandering has grown substantially, providing us with new and exciting insights into human attention and cognition, more broadly.  One issue within this line of research that has received little attention, however, is the heterogeneity in researchers’ conceptualizations of mind wandering. Many researchers differ in their definitions of mind wandering and, naturally, construct thought sampling probes aimed at measuring rates of mind wandering according to their held definitions. In spite of this, researchers tend to cite findings from studies on mind wandering assuming they all refer to the same phenomenon. The present study aims to test this assumption. In this study, participants completed a SART containing thought probes taken from three of the most commonly cited papers on mind wandering. We hypothesize that rates of mind wandering will differ between probe types within the same task, suggesting that not all measures of mind wandering are comparable.

q2.value:
We expect that overall rates of mind wandering and on-task reports will differ as a function of probe type, however we do not have any strong predictions as to how specific probe types will differ in their measurement of these variables.

For the sake of completion, we also intend to test whether performance on the task differs as a function of probe type. We hypothesize that groups will not differ in accuracy scores on the SART.

Finally, one exploratory point of analysis concerns how mind wandering and on-task rates differ with time-on-task. Although we predict that these variables will differ with time-on-task as a function of probe type, we have no strong predictions as to how specific probe types will lead to differences in time-on-task effects.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our study has a between-subjects design, with 1 between-subjects factor (probe type) with 3 levels.

q7.value: Participant groups of 1-4 will be assigned to one of the three conditions, with group condition rotating between the three possible conditions until one group hits the target sample size. At this point, group conditions will alternate between the remaining groups until all three have reached the target sample size.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Data for this study has been collected and stored on a password-protected lab drive to which the researchers involved in this study have access. In order to prevent any researcher biases, data for this study was collected entirely by research assistants. In other words, the researchers did not witness participants performing the experimental task. Moreover, the researchers have agreed not to access the data until preregistration is complete.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the SONA undergraduate participant pool at the University of Waterloo, where they will be compensated in 1% of bonus course credit for their participation. Paritipants must be at least 18 years of age to participate.

q11.value: Our sample consists of approximately 50 participants per group.

q12.value: Our target sample size was 80 participants per group, which is generally considered well-powered for detecting moderate effects, however due to university closures related to the spread of COVID-19, we have been forced to end data collection early. Our final sample size consists of approximately 50 participants per group.

question.value:
* Probe Type (McVay, Christoff, Mason) + relevant verbal instructions (see attachment)

* Digit size  (1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, or 3.5 degrees of visual angle) (part of the SART, not directly relevant to any research question)

Participant-level:
* Gender
* Age
* Handedness

Trial-level:
* Response (go/nogo)
* SART reaction time
* SART response accuracy
* Probe response
* Probe reaction time

We will use Bayesian hierarchical logistic regression models via the R package 'brms' to conduct the following analyses:

* Compare mind-wandering rates (and variance in rates) between probe types
* Compare on-task rates (and variance in rates) between probe type
* Compare SART accuracies between probe types (expect no difference)


We will use Bayesian hierarchical linear regression models via the R package 'brms' to conduct the following analyses:

* Compare probe reaction times between probe types
* Compare SART reaction times between probe types


For each of these models, we will use the R package 'emmeans' to obtain the probability distribution for the mean outcome variable for each probe type from our models. We will thenthen generate probability distributions for the differences between each pair of groups by subtracting the samples of one group from another.

q18.value:
We will convert responses on the different probes to binary measures of mind-wandering and on-task (based on methods for measuring "mind-wandering" reported in respective papers):

* Mason (2007): 2-AFC, "Were you just having an irrelevant thought?" (Yes/No). 'Yes' = mind-wandering, 'No' = on-task.

* Christoff (2009): 7-point likert-type scale, "Where was your attention focused just before the probe?" (1 (on-task) to 7 (off-task)): Responses 1 through 3 considered "on-task", responses 5 through 7 considered "mind-wandering".

* McVay (2009): 7-AFC, "What were you just thinking about?" ("The task", "Task experience/performance", "Everyday stuff", "Current state of being", "Personal worries", "Daydreams", or "Other"). "The task" = on-task, all other responses other than "Task experience/performance" = mind-wandering.

Additionally all reaction times will be log-transformed and z-scored prior to analysis, but the results of our reaction-time models will be back-transformed into raw reaction times after analysis for reporting and visualization.

These transformations will be done in R prior to statistical modelling.

q19.value: For statistical inference, we will use Bayesian Highest Desnity Intervals (HDIs) to test differences in means between groups. To evaluate differences between group means, we will use two criteria: if the 90% HDI (as recommended in the official Stan user's guide) does not include zero, we will consider the difference to be "highly credible". If the 90% HDI includes zero but the 60% HDI does not (i.e 80% or more of the samples are above/below zero), we will consider the difference "weakly credible". If the 60% HDI includes zero, we will conclude there to be no credible difference between the group means.

q20.value: Participants who were flagged by our research assistants as being problematic (e.g. people who were seen using their cell phones during the task, or people who completed the task during loud construction in the building) will excluded from the data prior to analysis. No other exclusion criteria will be applied, as multi-level models are generally robust to outliers and are thus not of strong concern in this study.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete a minimum of 15 thought probes, they will be discarded from further analysis.

q22.value: We will likely investigate how our dependent variables of interest (rates of mind wandering, on task reports and SART performance) vary with time on task.

registration_responses.q2:
We expect that overall rates of mind wandering and on-task reports will differ as a function of probe type, however we do not have any strong predictions as to how specific probe types will differ in their measurement of these variables.

For the sake of completion, we also intend to test whether performance on the task differs as a function of probe type. We hypothesize that groups will not differ in accuracy scores on the SART.

Finally, one exploratory point of analysis concerns how mind wandering and on-task rates differ with time-on-task. Although we predict that these variables will differ with time-on-task as a function of probe type, we have no strong predictions as to how specific probe types will lead to differences in time-on-task effects.
